column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: 'Whatever the nature of the privilege of confidentiality of Presidential communications in the exercise of Art II powers, the privilege can be said to derive from the supremacy of each branch within its own assigned area of constitutional duties.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Certain powers and privileges flow from the nature of enumerated powers
column10: the protection of the confidentiality of Presidential communications has similar constitutional underpinnings.'

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: 'The expectation of a President to the confidentiality of his conversations and correspondence, like the claim of confidentiality of judicial deliberations, for example, has all the values to which we accord deference for the privacy of all citizens and, added to those values, is the necessity for protection of the public interest in candid, objective, and even blunt or harsh opinions in Presidential decision making.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: A President and those who assist him must be free to explore alternatives in the process of shaping policies and making decisions and to do so in a way many would be unwilling to express except privately

column5: governments definition executive privilege

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Executive privilege may properly be asserted in response to a congressional subpoena seeking testimony by the Counsel to the President concerning the performance of official duties on the basis that the Counsel serves as an immediate adviser to the President and is therefore immune from compelled congressional testimony

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Accordingly, "[n]ot only can the President invoke executive privilege to protect [his personal staff] from the necessity of answering questions posed by a congressional committee, but he can also direct them not even to appear before the committee."^

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: However, neither the doctrine of separation of powers, nor the need for confidentiality of high level communications, without more, can sustain an absolute, unqualified Presidential privilege of immunity from judicial process under all circumstances.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Since the beginnings of our nation, executive officials have claimed a variety of privileges to resist disclosure of informa- tion the confidentiality of which they felt was crucial to fulfillment of the unique role and responsibilities of the executive branch of our government.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Courts ruled early that the executive had a right to withhold documents that might reveal military or state secrets

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: The courts have also granted the executive a right to withhold the identity of government informers in some circumstances, Roviaro v. United States, 353 U.S. 53, 59-61 (1957), and a qualified right to withhold information related to pending investigations.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: See Friedman v. Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Inc., 738 F.2d 1336, 1341-43 (D.C.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Other privileges sanctioned by the Supreme Court include the grant of absolute immunity to the President from civil liability for official acts, see Nixon v. Fitzgerald, 457 U.S. 731, 749 (1982) (Fitzgerald), and from judicial compulsion to perform a discretionary act

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: The most frequent form of executive privilege raised in the judicial arena is the deliberative process privilege
column10: it allows the government to withhold documents and other materials that would reveal "advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which govern- mental decisions and policies are formulated."

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: The executive privilege recognizes the need to protect open discussions among governmental officials and their staff:A fundamental part of the decisional process is the analysis of different options and alternatives.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: Advisory communications, from a subordinate to a governmental officer, which examine and analyze these choices, are often essential to this process.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: The making of candid communications by the subordinate may well be hampered if their contents are expected to become public knowledge.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: To ensure more informed decisionmaking, the privilege protects confidential advisory and deliberative communications between government officials at all levels of government and those who assist them in formulating and deciding upon future governmental action.

column5: governments definition executive privilege
column9: [e]xecutive privilege is the government's privilege to prevent disclosure of certain information whose disclosure would be contrary to the public interest and that police investigations "are made under a veil of confidentiality and that it would contravene the public interest and would impair the functioning of the police department if the results of such investigations were disclosed."

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Available published series report that the immediate operative mortality rate for both vertical banded gastroplasty and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is relatively low.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: On the other hand, morbidity in the early postoperative period, i.e., wound infections, dehiscence, leaks from staple line breakdown, stomal stenosis, marginal ulcers, various pulmonary problems, and deep thrombophlebitis in the aggregate, may be as high as 10 percent or more.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: In the later postoperative period, other problems may arise and may require reoperation.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: These are pouch and distal esophageal dilation, persistent vomiting (with or without stomal obstruction), cholecystitis, or failure to lose weight.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Moreover, mortality and morbidity rates with reoperation are higher than those of primary operations.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: In the long term, micronutrient deficiencies, particularly of vitamin B[12] folate, and iron, are common after gastric bypass and must be sought and treated.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Another potential result of this operation is the so-called "dumping syndrome," which is characterized by gastrointestinal distress and other symptoms.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Occasionally, these symptoms may not respond to conservative measures and may be troublesome to the patient.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Many data suggest that deficient nutrition in pregnancy carries with it a high risk of fetal damage or loss.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: This is of particular concern because as many as 80 percent of patients having weight reduction surgery are women of childbearing age.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: In view of the uncertain frequency and effects on fetal development of rapid weight loss, micro- or macronutrient deficiency, or other metabolic sequelae of these procedures, secure birth control methods should be provided for these patients during this period of weight loss.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: They should be informed that maternal malnutrition may impair normal fetal development.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Women who become pregnant after these surgical procedures need special attention from the clinical care team.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery
column9: Euphoria can be seen in patients during the early postoperative period.

column5: possible complications potential dangers gastric bypass surgery

column9: He had received the commission for the Luverne mural in May of 1941.

column5: show examples murals
column9: In February of 1942, while completing the project, he needed a letter for his draft board from the Section to allow him to finish the work.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Getz seems to have managed to complete the mural and send it to Luverne for installation only a week or ten days before he was to be inducted into military service.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Tuscumbia: "Chief Tuscumbia Greets the Dickson Family," Jack McMillan, 1939.

column5: show examples murals
column9: McMillan, a New York artist, chose the theme of his mural after visiting Tuscumbia shortly after receiving the commission.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Section had proposed that he consider using Helen Keller, but the residents of Tuscumbia suggested the arrival of Michael Dickson and his family.

column5: show examples murals
column9: McMillan actually produced sketches using both themes and the Section office chose the Dickson panel as "unusually handsome in its simplicity and plastic qualities."

column5: show examples murals
column9: The mural seems to have been very well received by the residents of Tuscumbia.

column5: show examples murals
column9: A long newspaper article appeared after the mural was installed elucidating the story of the Dickson family who arrived by river in Tuscumbia after fleeing the Johnson massacre in Tennessee.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Chief Tuscumbia greeted them and sold them a large tract of land for $5.00 and two pole axes.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Brewton: "Logging," John von Wicht, 1939 (missing).

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Brewton mural is the one mural which today is missing.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Originally from Germany, but in 1939 a resident of New York City, von Wicht chose as his theme the early history of the lumber industry in the area around Brewton.

column5: show examples murals
column9: When it was installed it was met with many favorable comments by the postmaster and the citizens in Brewton.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Carrollton: "Farm Scene with Senator Bankhead," Stuart R. Purser, 1943.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Several local groups from Carrollton and the postmaster had written to Washington to request that their town be given a mural and that it honor and depict U. S. senator John H. Bankhead, Jr., who had helped them secure the federal building/post office it was to decorate.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The mural was awarded to Stuart Purser of Louisiana, who complied with the thematic choice of the citizens of Carrollton.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The final panel shows Bankhead talking with a farmer in front of a typical Alabama farm using the newer methods of terracing and field rotation introduced by the Bankhead farm programs.

column5: show examples murals
column9: When the mural was completed the head of the Carrollton Civic Club wrote to the Section: "We are very proud of the mural and it looks so well in place.

column5: show examples murals
column9: I think Mr. Purser caught the idea we had in mind and has put in the picture not only the atmosphere of our county but conveys as well the thought that Mr. Bankhead was particularly interested in that part of life."

column5: show examples murals
column9: Eutaw: "The Countryside," Robert Gwathmey, 1941.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The panel by Gwathmey was the Alabama winner of the 1939 48 States Competition.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Although Gwathmey had entered the competition with a panel designed for the post office in Phoebus, Virginia, he was invited to rework his design for the Alabama site.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Gwathmey wrote to the postmaster and the local newspaper editor for ideas.

column5: show examples murals
column9: When he got no reply from them he visited the site and discussed a possible theme with the local county agricultural agent.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He settled on a local lumber industry scene: the method of stacking pine boards for drying.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Although today considered a very nice work, this was one of the few Alabama works which did not receive an enthusiastic initial review.

column5: show examples murals
column9: When the postmaster at Eutaw wrote to the Section to verify the panel's final installation he included a short note: "We have but one newspaper and I asked the editor to give the mural a write up in the next issue, and was told that he had nothing to say."

column5: show examples murals
column9: Fairfield: "Spirit of Steel," *Frank Hartley Anderson, 1938.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Anderson, an Alabama artist, produced probably the most direct illustration of a local industry.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The scene and its relationship to Fairfield were described by Anderson in a letter to the Section: "Fairfield itself is entirely devoted to steel and iron, this covering of course the mining of coal and iron and the quarrying of limestone and dolomite, bringing them together and making iron, then steel, and into the finished bars, plates, structural steel, wire and nails.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The central motif, in the center, rear, is the converter 'up,' which Fairfield knows to mean 'all's right with the world.'

column5: show examples murals
column9: The flaming torch it makes as air is blown in lights up the sky for miles around.

column5: show examples murals
show examples murals
column9: At the right and left are the stacks of the steel mill, with cooling towers, and the furnaces making pig iron.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Below, at right and left, are the coal mines and the iron ore mines, both entirely underground.

column5: show examples murals
column9: In the center, right and left, are the scenes 'changing the furnace' and 'making bottom,' both important parts of the needed processes."

column5: show examples murals
column9: Anderson also wrote the Section office that 99% of the people using the post office were connected with the local steel industry and all seemed pleased with the mural.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Fort Payne: "Harvest at Fort Payne," Harwood Steiger, 1938.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Steiger, of New York, admitted he had never been as far south as Fort Payne when he received the invitation to produce a mural there.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Steiger did make a trip to Fort Payne within a month and found the postmaster most helpful as he prepared his sketches.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The postmaster, in fact, told Steiger that he was pleased to be getting a mural although he had never heard of one before and he drove Steiger out into the country to see waterfalls.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Steiger proposed two different sketches for the mural: one showing the cotton industry in town and the other a landscape.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He and the Section both chose the "pretty landscape" as more pleasing.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Guntersville: "Indians Receiving Gifts from the Spanish," Charles Russell Hardman, 1947.

column5: show examples murals
column9: A very late addition to the program, little information about the Guntersville mural is known.

column5: show examples murals
column9: There are no files or documents in the National Archives relating to it.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Hardman was a Florida artist who had done some earlier work for the Section, including a mural in Miami Beach on a similar theme.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Haleyville: "Reforestation," Hollis Holbrooke, 1940.

column5: show examples murals
column9: After he made a trip to Haleyville, Holbrooke chose to paint a scene of recent conservation work in the area of the Black Warrior Forest.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He consulted both the postmaster, who wanted a picture of wildlife feeding in a forest setting, and the local forest ranger,who thought the picture should mean more to the people of the area than simply a pretty picture.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Holbrooke seems to have agreed and chose to document the benefits of both reforestation programs and land terracing to combat soil erosion, which he compared to the older, less effective methods of erosion control.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Holbrooke also wrote a lengthy explanatory note for the local newspaper about the mural and benefits of reforestation.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The two figures in the panel represent a C.C.C. worker and the forest ranger, Mr. Thomas Wilson.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Hartselle: "Cotton Scene," Lee R. Warthen, 1941.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Warthen, of Washington, D.C., produced the Hartselle panel as the result of his entry into the War Department Building Competition.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Warthen did extensive research for the panel, wrote the local postmaster, and talked with U.S. House member John Sparkman, who was from Hartselle, about the local industry and activities used in the final panel.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Huntsville: "Tennessee Valley Authority," Xavier Gonzalez, 1937.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Huntsville mural was the largest and most expensive panel commissioned in Alabama and the only one placed in a federal courthouse rather than a post office.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Gonzales received the invitation for the panel based on designs he had submitted for a competition in Jackson, Mississippi, in 1936.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He originally proposed a rather odd allegorical panel that the Washington office criticized for both its style and its lack of meaning for the people in Huntsville.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Instead of making allegorical allusions it was suggested that Gonzalez place emphasis on the realities of life.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Using a realistic style and basing his new theme on the work then being done by TVA in northern Alabama, he redesigned the panel several times.

column5: show examples murals
column9: It was ultimately put in place in October of 1937 and described by Gonzales: "Huntsville, Alabama is situated in the lower angle of the Tennessee River and has profited immensely by the benefits derived from the Muscle Shoals Project.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Before this undertaking was begun, the country, being unprotected, was at the mercy of floods and calamities.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The benefits of electricity were a privilege of the few who could afford the exorbitant price, the soil of the country was being washed away by the floods, and industry and agriculture were underdeveloped due to the uncertainty of land conditions.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Since the completion of this project tremendous benefits have been received . . . the control and proper use of water resources
column10: . . . conservation and preservation of land resources
column11: . . . [and] the disposition of surplus electric energy created as a by-product of the irrigation and flood control."

column5: show examples murals

column5: show examples murals
column9: Getz received the commission for Luverne on the basis of designs he had submitted for a competition for the War Department building.

column5: show examples murals
column9: As a northern artist he was warned by the Section when he proposed the theme of cotton: "It will be necessary for you to acquaint yourself thoroughly with the appearance of a cotton plant as the individuals using this post office will be especially observant on this point."

column5: show examples murals
column9: Getz consulted southern painters as well as researching the growing of cotton while he worked on the mural.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The story of the completion of Getz's mural was all too familiar late in the Section program.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He had received the commission for the Luverne mural in May of 1941.

column5: show examples murals
column9: In February of 1942, while completing the project, he needed a letter for his draft board from the Section to allow him to finish the work.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Getz seems to have managed to complete the mural and send it to Luverne for installation only a week or ten days before he was to be inducted into military service.

column9: Monroeville: "Harvesting," *Arthur Leroy Bairnsfather, 1939.

column5: show examples murals
column9: A.L. Bairnsfather, of Birmingham, submitted three initial sketches to the Section after his invitation to do the Monroeville mural.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Section chose a harvesting scene even though Bairnsfather suggested to them that there was actually very little grain grown in the area.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Montevallo: "Early Settlers Weighing Cotton," William Sherrod McCall, 1939.

column5: show examples murals
column9: McCall, at the time from Jacksonville, Florida, received the invitation to do the Montevallo mural in 1938 on the basis of designs he had submitted for a competition in Miami.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He immediately visited Montevallo and chose the theme of cotton and settlement of the region because,in his words, "Montevallo was a very important little town to the cotton industry of the State in the early days."

column5: show examples murals
column9: The postmaster, in the letter written to verify the installation of the mural, commented: "I would like to state that the citizens find the work a beautiful addition to our building and wish to thank the Federal government for this contribution.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The heads of the Departments in our Alabama State College, as well as those students who are able to comment upon Mr. McCall's workmanship, join me in saying that it is one of the best pieces of work seen in the State."

column5: show examples murals
column9: McCall wrote a final letter to the Section in which he commented upon his royal treatment in Montevallo.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Oneonta: "Local Agriculture--A.A.A. 1939," Aldis B. Browne, 1939.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Browne's Oneonta panel depicts a series of local scenes, all of them suggestions from the people of Oneonta.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Also noteworthy about the Oneonta mural was the working method used by Browne.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He came to Oneonta from Connecticut and painted the work directly on the wall to the delight of the local citizens, who apparently came by daily to inspect his progress.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Browne reported to the Section office that he was "nuts" about Oneonta, and that the greatest debate going on was whether the jug on the wall held corn whiskey, since Blount County was dry.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Included in the scheme, behind the central figures, are the specific local scenes and buildings requested by the postmaster and local citizens: to the left the city of Birmingham dam, which was located seven miles from the town, and on the right a local strip mine.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Across the top are local Oneonta buildings: the Baptist and Methodist churches, the post office, cotton warehouse, sawmill, courthouse and jail.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Finishing the background is a house and a covered bridge.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Browne was pleased to report to the Section that the central section, comparing a terraced field to one neglected and worn by erosion was already being used by the local agricultural office to show farmers the benefits of modern scientific methods of planting.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The letter written by the postmaster to verify the final installation of the panel was effusive in its praise for the Section, Browne, and the mural.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Opp: "Opp," Hans Mangelsdorf, 1940.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Opp received a very nice sculptural commission by Mangelsdorf, a New Orleans artist, who within a month of receiving the invitation visited Opp.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He sent not only sketches to the Section office but also his assurance that he had tried to include everything the people of Opp suggested as important for a representation of their town.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The final piece was described in a local newspaper after installation: "In the relief agriculture is personified by the woman holding a basket of corn in one hand and flowers in the other hand, and the church in the background indicates home, life, and education.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The goldenrod, the State flower, and the Flicker, the State bird, are also shown on the relief.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Industry is personified by the man holding a spool, symbolizing the main industry of the town, the cotton mills.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The water tower, symbol of the industrial progress, shows in the background, and in the back of all is the long leaf pine."

column5: show examples murals
column9: Ozark: "Early Industry in Dale County," *Kelly Fitzpatrick, 1938.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Ozark panel was the first of two murals painted by Wetumpka artist John Kelly Fitzpatrick, with Phenix City the second.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Fitzpatrick was awarded the commission on the basis of work he had done under TRAP, an earlier Treasury program.

column5: show examples murals
column9: He actually proposed several different themes, including a scene from local history depicting a famous battle between Samuel Dale and local native Americans, a decorative and allegorical panel, and a postal history panel.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Section however wanted him to try a local industry theme.

column5: show examples murals
column9: They suggested as a model the easel painting of a mill that he had previously produced under PWAP, and which was then hanging in the White House.

column5: show examples murals
column9: That sketch was ultimately approved and used.

column5: show examples murals
column9: When the mural was installed a notice in the local paper complimented it highly.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Phenix City: "Cotton," *Kelly Fitzpatrick, 1939.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Phenix City panel was the second of two murals by Fitzpatrick, a Wetumpka artist, with Ozark the first.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Its theme is the southern cotton crop.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Before it was installed in the Phenix City post office it was exhibited at the Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts and described in the local newspaper: "The subject of the mural is a cotton growth cycle showing the various steps from the planting of the seed to weaving it into cloth.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The scene is a typical east Alabama landscape where one gently rolling hill rises above another and on each succeeding level a period of growth is depicted."

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Phenix City mural is still in place although the building is now the public library.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Russellville: "Shipment of First Iron Produced in Russellville," Conrad A. Albrizzio, 1938.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The mural for Russellville turned out to be one of the most controversial in Alabama.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Albrizzio submitted two sketches of local industry shortly after he was invited to undertake the commission.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Section office chose the scene of a local quarry over that of an early iron mine.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Section apparently made their decision in early July 1937 and by the end of the month they had received numerous telegrams in protest from Russellville clubs and business concerns.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The local population proposed a slightly different theme of the old Alabama Iron Works, the first iron furnace in Alabama, built in 1817.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Similar letters were also sent from Alabama to Senator John H. Bankhead, Jr., in Washington.

column5: show examples murals
column9: One of the letters described the general theme and the details the Russellville businessmen wished to have included: "We know the beehive shape of all charcoal furnaces erected at the date.

column5: show examples murals
column9: We know that the furnace and forge were motivated by water power through a race that still exists.

column5: show examples murals
column9: We know they used a five hundred pound hammer to shape the pig--we have the hammer.

column5: show examples murals
column9: We know the ore was collected by slave labor and hauled in ox carts to the furnace.

column5: show examples murals
column9: We know the pig iron, much of it, was hauled by ox wagon thirty-five miles to the Tennessee River and shipped to Liverpool, England, and we have the records where it was sold at one hundred dollars a ton.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The rock wall foundation of the warehouse still stands along the creek bank."

column5: show examples murals
column9: After a series of letters between Albrizzio, Bankhead, the citizens of Russellville, and the Section, Albrizzio redesigned to the wishes of the local population and eventually went to Russellville and painted the mural in fresco on the walls of the post office.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Scottsboro: "Alabama Agriculture," Constance Ortmayer, 1940.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Ortmayer was teaching at Rollins College in Florida when she received the invitation to do a panel in Scottsboro.

column5: show examples murals
column9: She chose a theme based on Alabama agriculture, especially cotton and corn.

column5: show examples murals
column9: She described the final images: "Three phases of cotton growing form the theme of the central panel.

column5: show examples murals
column9: On the right the cultivation of the crop is symbolized by the young man working with a hoe among the new plants.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Opposite a young woman is depicted picking ripened bolls, and for the background, the processing and shipping of cotton is represented by the bales and the strong figure of a second young worker standing between them.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Both of the flanking panels interpret the growing of corn.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The young man and woman shown on the right are examining the fruit on the ripened stalks and the couple on the left are represented as workers who have harvested the new crop."

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Section office wrote about the work in these words: "In a sculpture characterized by clean, flowing lines, Miss Ortmayer gives an exceptionally effective representation of the youthful strength and grace that each new generation brings to the agriculture of the south."

column9: Mural Characteristically, Portinari's first painting, Discovery of the Land, is dominated not by captains or the admirals or the priests of the conquest but by the common sailors who manned the fleet.

column9: This mural has the most baroque composition of the series.

column5: show examples murals

column5: show examples murals

column5: show examples murals
column9: The wind of conquest and of expectation seems to blow through the picture and the effect is heightened by the Tiepolo-like blues and greys and whites, the true tonalities of the sea, that predominate.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Mural The second painting, Entry into the Forest, is reminiscent of frescoes in the Brazilian Ministry of Education.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The idea of representing tropical animals, birds, and insects in a jungle setting derives from the decorations of the dining room Portinari prepared for the Rio de Janeiro residence of Senhor Josï¿½ Nabuco.

column5: show examples murals
column9: This mural contrasts with the first in that the composition is more static and the figures more solidly realized.

column5: show examples murals
column9: Yet there is the same insistence upon essential things in the meticulous rendering of the hands and arms of the explorers and the almost unfinished aspect of the figure of the drinking man beside the stream.

column5: show examples murals
column9: The Teaching of the Indians, built around a classic triangular arrangement of figures, follows the sober, contained tradition of Portinari's early work.

column9: As with the Discovery mural, the artist originally planned a different composition.

column9: The mural over the entrance to the Hearing Room depicts an incident in the reign of Caesar Augustus Octavius.

column9: No such flag or pennant may be placed above the flag of the United States or to the United States flag's right.

column9: When the flag of the United States is displayed from a staff projecting horizontally or at an angle from the window sill, balcony, or front of a building, the union of the flag should be placed at the peak of the staff unless the flag is at half-staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended over a sidewalk from a rope extending from a house to a pole at the edge of the sidewalk, the flag should be hoisted out, union first, from the building.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed either horizontally or vertically against a wall, the union should be uppermost and to the flag's own right, that is, to the observer's left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed in a window, the flag should be displayed in the same way, with the union or blue field to the left of the observer in the street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed over the middle of the street, it should be suspended vertically with the union to the north in an east and west street or to the east in a north and south street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When used on a speaker's platform, the flag, if displayed flat, should be displayed above and behind the speaker.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed from a staff in a church or public auditorium, the flag of the United States of America should hold the position of superior prominence, in advance of the audience, and in the position of honor at the clergyman's or speaker's right as he faces the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Any other flag so displayed should be placed on the left of the clergyman or speaker or to the right of the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should form a distinctive feature of the ceremony of unveiling a statute or monument, but it should never be used as the covering for the statute or monument.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag, when flown at half-staff, should be first hoisted to the peak for an instant and then lowered to the half-staff position.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be again raised to the peak before it is lowered for the day.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: On Memorial Day, the flag should be displayed at half-staff until noon only, then raised to the top of the staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: By order of the President, the flag shall be flown at half-staff upon the death of principal figures of the United States Government and the Governor of a state, territory, or possession, as a mark of respect to their memory.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of other officials or foreign dignitaries, the flag is to be displayed at half-staff according to Presidential instructions or orders, or in accordance with recognized customs or practices not inconsistent with law.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of a present or former official of the government of any state, territory, or possession of the United States, the Governor of that State, territory, or possession may proclaim that the National flag shall be flown at halfstaff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag shall be flown at half-staff thirty days from the death of the President or a former President
column10: ten days from the day of death of the VicePresident, the Chief Justice or a retired Chief Justice of the United States or the Speaker of the House of Representatives
column11: from the day of death until interment of an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, a Secretary of an executive or military department, a former Vice-President, or the Governor of a state, CRS-6 territory, or possession
column12: and on the day of death and the following day for a Member of Congress.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag shall be flown at half-staff on Peace Officers Memorial Day, unless that day is also Armed Forces Day.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: As used in this subsection--(1) The term "half-staff" means the position of the flag when it is one-half the distance between the top and bottom of the staff
column10: (2) the term "executive or military department" means any agency listed under Sections 101 and 102 of Title 5, United States Code
column11: and (3) the term "Member of Congress" means a Senator, a Representative, a Delegate, or the Resident Commissioner from Puerto Rico.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is used to cover a casket, it should be so placed that the union is at the head and over the left shoulder.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be lowered into the grave or allowed to touch the ground.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended across a corridor or lobby in a building with only one main entrance, it should be suspended vertically with the union of the flag to the observer's left upon entering.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If the building has more than one main entrance, the flag should be suspended vertically near the center of the corridor or lobby with the union to the north, when entrances are to the east and west or to the east when entrances are to the north and south.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If there are entrances in more than two directions, the union should be to the east.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No disrespect should be shown to the flag of the United States of America
column10: the flag should not be dipped to any person or thing.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Regimental colors, state flags, and organization or institutional flags are to be dipped as a mark of honor.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be displayed with union down, except as a signal of dire distress in instances of extreme danger to life or property.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never touch anything beneath it, such as the ground, the floor, water, or merchandise.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be carried flat or horizontally, but always aloft and free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as wearing apparel, bedding, or drapery.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should never be festooned, drawn back, nor up, in folds, but always allowed to fall free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Bunting of blue, white, and red, always arranged with the blue above, the white in the middle, and the red below, should be used for covering a speaker's desk, draping in front of the platform, and for a decoration in general.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be fastened, displayed, used, or stored in such a manner as to permit it to be easily torn, soiled, or damaged in any way.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: CRS-7 (f) The flag should never be used as a covering for a ceiling.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never have placed upon it, nor on any part of it, nor attached to it any mark, insignia, letter, word, figure, design, picture, or drawing of any nature.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as a receptacle for receiving, holding, carrying, or delivering anything.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used for advertising purposes in any manner whatsoever.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should not be embroidered on such articles as cushions or handkerchiefs and the like, printed or otherwise impressed on paper napkins or boxes or anything that is designed for temporary use and discard.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Advertising signs should not be fastened to a staff or halyard from which the flag is flown.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No part of the flag should ever be used as a costume or athletic uniform.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: However, a flag patch may be affixed to the uniform of military personnel, firemen, policemen, and members of patriotic organizations.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag represents a living country and is itself considered a living thing.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Therefore, the lapel flag pin being a replica, should be worn on the left lapel near the heart.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It is the universal custom to display the flag only from sunrise to sunset on buildings and on stationary flagstaffs in the open.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: However, when a patriotic effect is desired, the flag may be displayed 24 hours a day if properly illuminated during hours of darkness

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: As a matter of custom, and without specific statutory or official authorization, the flag is flown at night at many other sites, including the United States Capitol.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be displayed on days when the weather is inclement, except when an all weather flag is displayed

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The section provides that the President shall order the flag flown at half-staff for stipulated periods "upon the death of principal figures of the United States Government and the Governor of a state, territory, or possession."

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: After the death of other officials or foreign dignitaries, the flag may be flown at half-staff according to Presidential instructions or in accordance with recognized custom not inconsistent with law.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In addition the Governor of a state, territory, or possession may direct that the national flag be flown at half-staff, territory, or possession may direct that the national flag be flown at half-staff in the event of the death of a present or former official of the respective government.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Presidents also have ordered the fly to be flown at half-staff on the death of leading citizens, not covered by law, as a mark of official tribute to their service to the United States.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Martin Luther King, Jr. is among those who have been so honored.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In short, the rule is the flag of the United States should always be displayed with utmost dignity and respect and in the position of highest honor.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: To this end, the Code lists several illustrative ways in which the flag may be displayed with other flags.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No flag other than a church flag during services at sea should be displayed above the United States flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If all flags are displayed at the same height, the United States flag is to be given a place of superior prominence, to the right of other flags.37 This provision does not require the federal flag to be flown higher than any other flag so long as no flag is above it, but does require it to be flown to the right of all other flags if it is not above them

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the United States flag is displayed with the flags of states of the union or municipalities and not with the flags of other nations, the federal flag, which represents all states, should be flown above and at the center of the other flags.40 Where there is only one flag pole, the federal flag should be displayed above state or municipal flags

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The Code also states that the flag should never be used for advertising purposes in any manner whatsoever

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No other flag or pennant should be placed above or, if on the same level, to the right of the flag of the United States of America, except during church services conducted by naval chaplains at sea, when the church pennant may be flown above the flag during church services for the personnel of the Navy.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No person shall display the flag of the United Nations or any other national or international flag equal, above, or in a position of superior prominence or honor to or in place of the flag of the United States or any Territory or possession thereof: Provided, That nothing in this section shall make unlawful the continuance of the practice heretofore followed of displaying the flag of the United Nations in a position of superior prominence or honor, and other national flags in positions of equal prominence or honor, with that of the flag of the United States at the headquarters of the United Nations.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended across a corridor or lobby in a building with only one main entrance, it should be suspended vertically with the union of the flag to the observer's left upon entering.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If the building has more than one main entrance, the flag should be suspended vertically near the center of the corridor or lobby with the union to the north, when entrances are to the east and west or to the east when entrances are to the north and south.

column9: The flag should be displayed in or near every polling place on election days.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be displayed during school days in or near every schoolhouse.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag, when carried in a procession with another flag or flags, should be either on the marching right
column10: that is, the flag's own right, or, if there is a line of other flags, in front of the center of that line.

column9: The flag of the United States of America should be at the center and at the highest point of the group when a number of flags of States or localities or pennants of societies are grouped and displayed from staffs.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When flags of States, cities, or localities, or pennants of societies are flown on the same halyard with the flag of the United States, the latter should always be at the peak.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flags are flown from adjacent staffs, the flag of the United States should be hoisted first and lowered last.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No such flag or pennant may be placed above the flag of the United States or to the United States flag's right.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag of the United States is displayed from a staff projecting horizontally or at an angle from the window sill, balcony, or front of a building, the union of the flag should be placed at the peak of the staff unless the flag is at half staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended over a sidewalk from a rope extending from a house to a pole at the edge of the sidewalk, the flag should be hoisted out, union first, from the building.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed either horizontally or vertically against a wall, the union should be uppermost and to the flag's own right, that is, to the observer's left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed in a window, the flag should be displayed in the same way, with the union or blue field to the left of the observer in the street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed over the middle of the street, it should be suspended vertically with the union to the north in an east and west street or to the east in a north and south street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When used on a speaker's platform, the flag, if displayed flat, should be displayed above and behind the speaker.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed from a staff in a church or public auditorium, the flag of the United States of America should hold the position of superior prominence, in advance of the audience, and in the position of honor at the clergyman's or speaker's right as he faces the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Any other flag so displayed should be placed on the left of the clergyman or speaker or to the right of the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag, when flown at half-staff, should be first hoisted to the peak for an instant and then lowered to the half-staff position.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be again raised to the peak before it is lowered for the day.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: On Memorial Day the flag should be displayed at half-staff until noon only, then raised to the top of the staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: By order of the President, the flag shall be flown at half-staff upon the death of principal figures of the United States Government and the Governor of a State, territory, or possession, as a mark of respect to their memory.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of other officials or foreign dignitaries, the flag is to be displayed at half-staff according to Presidential instructions or orders, or in accordance with recognized customs or practices not inconsistent with law.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of a present or former official of the government of any State, territory, or possession of the United States, the Governor of that State, territory, or possession may proclaim that the National flag shall be flown at half-staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be lowered into the grave or allowed to touch the ground.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended across a corridor or lobby in a building with only one main entrance, it should be suspended vertically with the union of the flag to the observer's left upon entering.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If the building has more than one main entrance, the flag should be suspended vertically near the center of the corridor or lobby with the union to the north, when entrances are to the east and west or to the east when entrances are to the north and south.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If there are entrances in more than two directions, the union should be to the east.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never touch anything beneath it, such as the ground, the floor, water, or merchandise.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be carried flat or horizontally, but always aloft and free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as wearing apparel, bedding, or drapery.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should never be festooned, drawn back, nor up, in folds, but always allowed to fall free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as a receptacle for receiving, holding, carrying, or delivering anything.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should not be embroidered on such articles as cushions or handkerchiefs and the like, printed or otherwise impressed on paper napkins or boxes or anything that is designed for temporary use and discard.

column9: Advertising signs should not be fastened to a staff or halyard from which the flag is flown.

column9: Display on or near administration building of public institutions--The flag should be displayed daily on or near the main administration building of every public institution.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column9: Display on or near administration building of public institutions--The flag should be displayed daily on or near the main administration building of every public institution.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Display in or near polling places--The flag should be displayed in or near every polling place on election days.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Display in or near schoolhouses--The flag should be displayed during school days in or near every schoolhouse.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be displayed on a float in a parade except from a staff, or as provided in subsection (i) of this section.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be draped over the hood, top, sides, or back of a vehicle or of a railroad train or a boat.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No person shall display the flag of the United Nations or any other national or international flag equal, above, or in a position of superior prominence or honor to, or in place of, the flag of the United States at any place within the United States or any Territory or possession thereof: Provided, That nothing in this section shall make unlawful the continuance of the practice heretofore followed of displaying the flag of the United Nations in a position of superior prominence or honor, and other national flags in positions of equal prominence or honor, with that of the flag of the United States at the headquarters of the United Nations.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
