column9: When it is displayed from the same flagpole with another flag - of a state, community, society or Scout unit - the flag of the United States must always be at the top except that the church pennant may be flown above the flag during church services for Navy personnel when conducted by a Naval chaplain on a ship at sea.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed over a street, it should be hung vertically, with the union to the north or east.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If the flag is suspended over a sidewalk, the flag's union should be farthest from the building.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When flown with flags of states, communities, or societies on separate flag poles which are of the same height and in a straight line, the flag of the United States is always placed in the position of honor - to its own right.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: ..The other flags may be smaller but none may be larger.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: ..No other flag ever should be placed above it.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: ..The flag of the United States is always the first flag raised and the last to be lowered.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When flown with the national banner of other countries, each flag must be displayed from a separate pole of the same height.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Each flag should be the same size.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: They should be raised and lowered simultaneously.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag of one nation may not be displayed above that of another nation.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Raising and Lowering the Flag The flag should be raised briskly and lowered slowly and ceremoniously.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Ordinarily it should be displayed only between sunrise and sunset.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should be illuminated if displayed at night.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Displaying the Flag Indoors When on display, the flag is accorded the place of honor, always positioned to its own right.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Place it to the right of the speaker or staging area or sanctuary.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Other flags should be to the left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag of the United States of America should be at the center and at the highest point of the group when a number of flags of states, localities, or societies are grouped for display.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When one flag is used with the flag of the United States of America and the staffs are crossed, the flag of the United States is placed on its own right with its staff in front of the other flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displaying the flag against a wall, vertically or horizontally, the flag's union (stars) should be at the top, to the flag's own right, and to the observer's left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Parading and Saluting the Flag When carried in a procession, the flag should be to the right of the marchers.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When other flags are carried, the flag of the United States may be centered in front of the others or carried to their right.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The Flag in Mourning To place the flag at half staff, hoist it to the peak for an instant and lower it to a position half way between the top and bottom of the staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag is to be raised again to the peak for a moment before it is lowered.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: On Memorial Day the flag is displayed at half staff until noon and at full staff from noon to sunset.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag is to be flown at half staff in mourning for designated, principal government leaders and upon presidential or gubernatorial order.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When used to cover a casket, the flag should be placed with the union at the head and over the left shoulder.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should not be lowered into the grave.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The pertinent section of the Flag Code says, "by order of the President, the flag shall be flown at half-staff upon the death of principal figures of the United States Government and the Governor of a State, territory, or possesion, as a mark of respect to their memory.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of other officials or foreign dignitaries, the flag is to be displayed at half-staff according to Presidential orders, or in accordance with recognized customs or practices not inconsistent with law.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death a present or former official of the government of any State, territory, or possession of the United States, the Governor of that state, territory, or possession may proclaim that the National flag shall be flown at half-staff."

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The code also includes other related details including the specific length of time during which the flag should be displayed at half-staff, in the event of the death of a "principal figure"(e.g., 30 days for the death of a sitting or former President, 10 days for the death of a sitting Vice-President,etc.).

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be displayed, from sunrise to sunset, on all days when the weather permits, especially on, New Year's Day Inauguration Day Martin Luther King's Birthday Presidents Day Easter Sunday Mother's Day Armed Forces Day Memorial Day (half-staff until noon) Flag Day Independence Day, July 4th Labor Day Constitution Day Columbus Day, October 12th Navy Day Veterans Day Thanksgiving Day Christmas Day Election Days and such other days as may be proclaimed by the President of the United States.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Display on buildings and stationary flagstaffs in open
column10: night display It is the universal custom to display the flag only from sunrise to sunset on buildings and on stationary flagstaffs in the open.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: However, when a patriotic effect is desired, the flag may be displayed twenty-four hours a day if properly illuminated during the hours of darkness.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Manner of hoisting The flag should be hoisted briskly and lowered ceremoniously.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Inclement weather The flag should not be displayed on days when the weather is inclement, except when an all weather flag is displayed.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Particular days of display The flag should be displayed on all days, especially on New Year's Day, January 1
column10: Inauguration Day, January 20
column11: Lincoln's Birthday, February 12
column12: Washington's Birthday, third Monday in February
column14: Mother's Day, second Sunday in May
column15: Armed Forces Day, third Saturday in May
column16: Memorial Day (half-staff until noon), the last Monday in May
column19: Labor Day, first Monday in September
column21: Columbus Day, second Monday in October
column24: Thanksgiving Day, fourth Thursday in November
column26: and such other days as may be proclaimed by the President of the United States
column27: the birthdays of States (date of admission)

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Display on or near administration building of public institutions The flag should be displayed daily on or near the main administration building of every public institution.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Display in or near polling places The flag should be displayed in or near every polling place on election days.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Display in or near schoolhouses The flag should be displayed during school days in or near every schoolhouse.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Position and manner of display The flag, when carried in a procession with another flag or flags, should be either on the marching right
column10: that is, the flag's own right, or, if there is a line of other flags, in front of the center of that line.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be displayed on a float in a parade except from a staff, or as provided in subsection (i) of this section.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be draped over the hood, top, sides, or back of a vehicle or of a railroad train or a boat.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed on a motorcar, the staff shall be fixed firmly to the chassis or clamped to the right fender.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No other flag or pennant should be placed above or, if on the same level, to the right of the flag of the United States of America, except during church services conducted by naval chaplains at sea, when the church pennant may be flown above the flag during church services for the personnel of the Navy.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No person shall display the flag of the United q q q q q q q q q q q q Nations or any other national or international flag equal, above, or in a position of superior prominence or honor to, or in place of, the flag of the United States at any place within the United States or any Territory or possession thereof: Provided, That nothing in this section shall make unlawful the continuance of the practice heretofore followed of displaying the flag of the United Nations in a position of superior prominence or honor, and other national flags in positions of equal prominence or honor, with that of the flag of the United States at the headquarters of the United Nations.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag of the United States of America, when it is displayed with another flag against a wall from crossed staffs, should be on the right, the flag's own right, and its staff should be in front of the staff of the other flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag of the United States of America should be at the center and at the highest point of the group when a number of flags of States or localities or pennants of societies are grouped and displayed from staffs.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When flags of States, cities, or localities, or pennants of societies are flown on the same halyard with the flag of the United States, the latter should always be at the peak.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flags are flown from adjacent staffs, the flag of the United States should be hoisted first and lowered last.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No such flag or pennant may be placed above the flag of the United States or to the United States flag's right.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag of the United States is displayed from a staff projecting horizontally or at an angle from the window sill, balcony, or front of a building, the union of the flag should be placed at the peak of the staff unless the flag is at half staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended over a sidewalk from a rope extending from a house to a pole at the edge of the sidewalk, the flag should be hoisted out, union first, from the building.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed either horizontally or vertically against a wall, the union should be uppermost and to the flag's own right, that is, to the observer's left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed in a window, the flag should be displayed in the same way, with the union or blue field to the left of the observer in the street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed over the middle of the street, it should be suspended vertically with the union to the north in an east and west street or to the east in a north and south street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When used on a speaker's platform, the flag, if displayed flat, should be displayed above and behind the speaker.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed from a staff in a church or public auditorium, the flag of the United States of America should hold the position of superior prominence, in advance of the audience, and in the position of honor at the clergyman's or speaker's right as he faces the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Any other flag so displayed should be placed on the left of the clergyman or speaker or to the right of the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should form a distinctive feature of the ceremony of unveiling a statue or monument, but it should never be used as the covering for the statue or monument.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag, when flown at half-staff, should be first hoisted to the peak for an instant and then lowered to the half-staff position.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be again raised to the peak before it is lowered for the day.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: On Memorial Day the flag should be displayed at half-staff until noon only, then raised to the top of the staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: By order of the President, the flag shall be flown at half-staff upon the death of principal figures of the United States Government and the Governor of a State, territory, or possession, as a mark of respect to their memory.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of other officials or foreign dignitaries, the flag is to be displayed at half-staff according to Presidential instructions or orders, or in accordance with recognized customs or practices not inconsistent with law.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of a present or former official of the government of any State, territory, or possession of the United States, the Governor of that State, territory, or possession may proclaim that the National flag shall be flown at half-staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag shall be flown at half-staff thirty days from the death of the President or a former President
column10: ten days from the day of death of the Vice President, the Chief Justice or a retired Chief Justice of the United States, or the Speaker of the House of Representatives
column11: from the day of death until interment of an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, a Secretary of an executive or military department, a former Vice President, or the Governor of a State, territory, or possession
column12: and on the day of death and the following day for a Member of Congress.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is used to cover a casket, it should be so placed that the union is at the head and over the left shoulder.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be lowered into the grave or allowed to touch the ground.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended across a corridor or lobby in a building with only one main entrance, it should be suspended vertically with the union of the flag to the observer's left upon entering.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If the building has more than one main entrance, the flag should be suspended vertically near the center of the corridor or lobby with the union to the north, when entrances are to the east and west or to the east when entrances are to the north and south.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If there are entrances in more than two directions, the union should be to the east.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Respect for flag No disrespect should be shown to the flag of the United States of America
column10: the flag should not be dipped to any person or thing.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Regimental colors, State flags, and organization or institutional flags are to be dipped as a mark of honor.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be displayed with the union down, except as a signal of dire distress in instances of extreme danger to life or property.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never touch anything beneath it, such as the ground, the floor, water, or merchandise.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be carried flat or horizontally, but always aloft and free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as wearing apparel, bedding, or drapery.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should never be festooned, drawn back, nor up, in folds, but always allowed to fall free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Bunting of blue, white, and red, always arranged with the blue above, the white in the middle, and the red below, should be used for covering a speaker's desk, draping the front of the platform, and for decoration in general.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be fastened, displayed, used, or stored in such a manner as to permit it to be easily torn, soiled, or damaged in any way.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as a covering for a ceiling.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never have placed upon it, nor on any part of it, nor attached to it any mark, insignia, letter, word, figure, design, picture, or drawing of any nature.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used as a receptacle for receiving, holding, carrying, or delivering anything.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used for advertising purposes in any manner whatsoever.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should not be embroidered on such articles as cushions or handkerchiefs and the like, printed or otherwise impressed on paper napkins or boxes or anything that is designed for temporary use and discard.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Advertising signs should not be fastened to a staff or halyard from which the flag is flown.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No part of the flag should ever be used as a costume or athletic uniform.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: However, a flag patch may be affixed to the uniform of military personnel, firemen, policemen, and members of patriotic organizations.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag represents a living country and is itself considered a living thing.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Therefore, the lapel flag pin being a replica, should be worn on the left lapel near the heart.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: U.S. flag in the position of highest honor (the observer's extreme left or the highest point in a grouping of flags)

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U.S. flag should be flown from the position of honor on the flag's own right, or from the flagpole on the left as normally viewed by the observer.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U. S. flag displayed from a staff either on a speaker's platform or at floor level in a public auditorium should occupy the position of honor to the speaker's right as the speaker faces the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the U.S. flag is displayed other than from a staff, it should be displayed flat, or so suspended that it folds fall free.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed over a street, place the union so it faces north or east, depending upon the direction of the street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed from a staff in a church or public auditorium, the flag of the United States of America should hold the position of superior prominence, in advance of the audience, and in the position of honor at the clergyman's or speaker 's right as he faces the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Any other flag so displayed should be placed on the left of the clergyman or speaker or to the right of the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U.S. flag, when carried in a procession with another or other flags, should be either on the marching right (the flag's own right) or, if there is a line of other flags,in front of the center of that line.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Never display the U.S. flag from a float except from a staff, or so suspended that its folds fall free as though staffed.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U.S. flag, when displayed with another flag against a wall from crossed staffs, should be on the U.S. flag's own right, and its staff should be in front of the staff of the other flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U.S. flag should be at the center and the highest point of the group when a number of flags of States or localities or pennants of societies are grouped and displayed from staffs.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When other flags are flown from the same halyard, the U.S. flag should always be at the peak.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When other flags are flown from adjacent staffs, the U.S. flag should be hoisted first and lowered last.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No flag may fly above or to the right of the U.S. flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If displayed flat against the wall on a speaker 's platform, the U.S. flag should be placed above and behind the speaker with the union of the flag in the upper left-hand corner as the audience faces the flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the U.S. flag is used to cover a casket, it should be so placed that the union is at the head and over the left shoulder.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be lowered into the grave or allowed to touch the ground.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag, when flown at half staff, should be first hoisted to the peak for a moment and then lowered to the half staff position.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be again raised to the peak before it is lowered for the day.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: A U.S. flag can be displayed on buildings and stationary flag staffs 24-hours a day if properly illuminated during the hours of darkness.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: To properly illuminate the U.S. flag, a light source must specifically placed to illuminate the U.S. flag so that a casual observer can recognize that it is the U.S. flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: On an automobile, tie the flag to the antenna or clamp the flagstaff to the right fender.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U.S. flag should never be displayed with the union down, except as a signal of distress.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The U.S. flag should never touch anything beneath it -- ground, floor, water, etc.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Never place anything on the U.S. flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never have placed upon it or attached to it any mark, sign, insignia, letter, word, figure, design, picture or drawing of any kind.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Never use the flag to hold, carry or deliver anything.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag

column9: When the flag is suspended over a sidewalk from a rope extending from house to pole at the edge of the sidewalk, the flag should be hoisted out from the building, toward the pole, union first.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed from a staff projecting horizontally or at an angle from the windowsill, balcony, or front of a building, the union of the fla g should go to the peak of the staff (unless the flag is to be displayed at half-mast).

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is used to cover a casket, it should be so placed that the union is at the head and over the left shoulder.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed in a manner other than being flown from a staff, it should be displayed flat, whether indoors or out.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed either horizontally or vertically against a wall, the union should be uppermost and to the flag's own right, that is, to the observer's left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When dis played in a window, it should be displayed in the same way, that is, with the union or blue field to the left of the observer in the street.When festoons, rosettes or draping are desired, bunting of blue, white and red should be used, but never the flag

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When carried in a procession with another flag or flags, the United States of America flag should be either on the marching right, or when there is a line of other flags, in front of the center of that line.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When a number of flags of states or cities or pennants of societies are grouped and displayed from staffs with our National flag, the latter should be at the center or at the highest point of the group.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The National flag shall be raised and lowered by hand.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Do not raise the flag while it is furled.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Unfurl, then hoist quickly to the top of the staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Lower it slowly and with dignity.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Place no objects on or over the flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: A speaker's table is sometimes covered with the flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: This practice should be avoided.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag shall be displayed with the union up.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag shall not be used as a portion of a costume or athletic uniform.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Do not embroider it upon cushions or handkerchiefs nor print it on paper napkins or boxes.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is used in unveiling a statue or monument, it should not serve as a covering of the object to be unveiled.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If it is displayed on such occasions, do not allow the flag to fall to the ground, but let it be carried aloft to form a feature of the ceremony.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be draped over the hood, top, sides, or back of a vehicle or of a railroad train or a boat.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed on a motorcar, the staff shall be fixed firmly to the chassis or clamped to the right fender.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No other flag or pennant should be placed above or, if on the same level, to the right of the flag of the United States of America, except during church services conducted by naval chaplains at sea, when the church pennant may be flown above the flag during church services for the personnel of the Navy.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No person shall display the flag of the United Nations or any other national or international flag equal, above, or in a position of superior prominence or honor to, or in place of, the flag of the United States at any place within the United States or any Territory or possession thereof.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Provided, That nothing in this section shall make unlawful the continuance of the practice heretofore followed of displaying the flag of the United Nations in a position of superior prominence or honor, and other national flags in positions of equal prominence or honor, with that of the flag of the United States at the headquarters of the United Nations.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag of the United States of America, when it is displayed with another flag against a wall from crossed staffs, should be on the right, the flag's own right, and its staff should be in front of the staff of the other flag.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag of the United States of America should be at the center and at the highest point of the group when a number of flags of States or localities or pennants of societies are grouped and displayed from staffs.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When flags of States, cities, or localities, or pennants of societies are flown on the same halyard with the flag of the United States, the latter should always be at the peak.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flags are flown from adjacent staffs, the flag of the United States should be hoisted first and lowered last.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: No such flag or pennant may be placed above the flag of the United States or to the United States flag's right.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag of the United States is displayed from a staff projecting horizontally or at an angle from the window sill, balcony, or front of a building, the union of the flag should be placed at the peak of the staff unless the flag is at half staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended over a sidewalk from a rope extending from a house to a pole at the edge of the sidewalk, the flag should be hoisted out, union first, from the building.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed either horizontally or vertically against a wall, the union should be uppermost and to the flag's own right, that is, to the observer's left.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed in a window, the flag should be displayed in the same way, with the union or blue field to the left of the observer in the street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed over the middle of the street, it should be suspended vertically with the union to the north in an east and west street or to the east in a north and south street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Image of USA flag displayed behind the speaker.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When used on a speaker's platform, the flag, if displayed flat, should be displayed above and behind the speaker.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When displayed from a staff in a church or public auditorium, the flag of the United States of America should hold the position of superior prominence, in advance of the audience, and in the position of honor at the clergyman's or speaker's right as he faces the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Any other flag so displayed should be placed on the left of the clergyman or speaker or to the right of the audience.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should form a distinctive feature of the ceremony of unveiling a statue or monument, but it should never be used as the covering for the statue or monument.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: Image of USA flag displayed at half-staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag, when flown at half-staff, should be first hoisted to the peak for an instant and then lowered to the half-staff position.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should be again raised to the peak before it is lowered for the day.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: On Memorial Day the flag should be displayed at half-staff until noon only, then raised to the top of the staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: By order of the President, the flag shall be flown at half-staff upon the death of principal figures of the United States Government and the Governor of a State, territory, or possession, as a mark of respect to their memory.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of other officials or foreign dignitaries, the flag is to be displayed at half-staff according to Presidential instructions or orders, or in accordance with recognized customs or practices not inconsistent with law.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: In the event of the death of a present or former official of the government of any State, territory, or possession of the United States, the Governor of that State, territory, or possession may proclaim that the National flag shall be flown at half-staff.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag shall be flown at half-staff thirty days from the death of the President or a former President
column10: ten days from the day of death of the Vice President, the Chief Justice or a retired Chief Justice of the United States, or the Speaker of the House of Representatives
column11: from the day of death until interment of an Associate justice of the Supreme Court, a Secretary of an executive or military department, a former Vice President, or the Governor of a State, territory, or possession
column12: and on the day of death and the following day for a Member of Congress.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is used to cover a casket, it should be so placed that the union is at the head and over the left shoulder.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should not be lowered into the grave or allowed to touch the ground.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is suspended across a corridor or lobby in a building with only one main entrance, it should be suspended vertically with the union of the flag to the observer's left upon entering.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If the building has more than one main entrance, the flag should be suspended vertically near the center of the corridor or lobby with the union to the north, when entrances are to the east and west or to the east when entrances are to the north and south.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: If there are entrances in more than two directions, the union should be to the east.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: When the flag is displayed over the middle of the street, it should be suspended vertically with the union to the north in an east and west street or to the east in a north and south street.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never touch anything beneath it, such as the ground, the floor, water, or merchandise.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: The flag should never be used for advertising purposes in any manner whatsoever.

column5: rules guidelines display united states flag
column9: It should not be embroidered on such articles as cushions or handkerchiefs and the like, printed or otherwise impressed on paper napkins or boxes or anything that is designed for temporary use and discard.

column5: social security means test
column9: Although I have written elsewhere that one might easily justify flattening the benefit structure in Social Security, especially in exchange for subsidies for saving, means testing is another matter.

column5: social security means test
column9: Means testing of a substantial portion of the elderly population could be considered degrading, and means testing is highly inaccurate given the ability to shift assets to children or simply hide them.

column5: social security means test
column9: Means testing also severely discourages saving for retirement

column5: social security means test
column9: Nonetheless, direct general revenue financing of Social Security might reduce the willingness to deal with our long-term problems and could raise a whole series of other debates such as whether to means-test Social Security benefits.

column5: social security means test
column9: Almost every American worker pays Social Security taxes and, upon retirement, receives a monthly benefit amount formulated on his or her lifetime earnings.

column5: social security means test
column9: It would be entirely inappropriate to penalize retired workers by reducing their Social Security benefits because they have successfully provided for their retirement with savings, investments and private pensions.

column5: social security means test
column9: Mr. Chairman, the Social Security earnings test is among the most unfair and counterproductive policies ever imposed by the Federal Government.

column5: social security means test
column9: The earnings test was originally imposed for a reason that now makes no economic sense.

column5: social security means test

column9: According to the hypothesis, the RET was introduced into the Social Security Act of 1935 because the designers of the program were motivated, at least in significant part, by the industrial policy objective of removing older workers from the workforce in order to make room for unemployed younger workers.

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test
column9: Under social insurance theory, the rationale for the RET is simple and straightforward: one must retire in order to receive a retirement benefit because loss of earnings due to retirement is the insured condition.

column5: social security means test

column9: A further element of unfairness results from the fact that the earnings test applies only to wage income.

column5: social security means test

column9: It should be noted that the earnings test also creates a kind of marriage penalty, because earnings by the primary Social Security recipient above the threshold can also reduce the benefits of auxiliary recipients.

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test

column5: social security means test
column9: Title I of the Act provided non-contributory, means-tested, old-age pensions, in the form of state welfare programs with federal funding.

column5: social security means test
column9: Title II of the Act, what is now thought of as Social Security, provided old-age insurance through a contributory social insurance scheme.

column5: social security means test
column9: The old-age insurance program required retirement from gainful employment as a condition of benefit receipt.

column5: social security means test
column9: For wage earners, this requirement was and is measured primarily by a test of earnings levels, hence the RET.

column5: social security means test
column9: The RET is simply the administrative form of the principle that one must be retired in order to collect retirement benefits from Social Security's old-age insurance program.

column5: social security means test
column9: In order to become eligible for SSDI, an individual must first have enough Social Security covered work-quarters and secondly have a severe impairment which makes him or her unable to do his or her previous work or any other kind of substantial gainful activity which exists in the national economy.

column5: social security means test
column9: Unlike SSDI, people receiving SSI because of blindness or disability have no work requirements, but must meet a financial means-test.

column5: social security means test
column9: Persons under age 65 must meet both disability and financial criteria, whereas those aged 65 or over need only meet the financial means-test.

column9: WHEREAS, the human embryo is a living organism of the species Homo sapiens at the earliest stages of development (including the single-celled stage), and human cloning creates a human being at the embryonic stage of life and grows this new human being solely to be exploited ("reproductive" cloning) or destroyed (so-called "therapeutic" cloning) through nontherapeutic research and experimentation
column10: and WHEREAS, human cloning is a manufacturing process in which a human being is created in a laboratory
column11: human cloning indicates a utilitarian view in which a human being is created merely for usefulness with no respect for the dignity of that human being
column12: and human cloning creates a human being who is the twin of a parent, has no other biological parent, and is the child of the grandparents thereby causing serious moral, social, and legal issues
column13: and WHEREAS, current human cloning attempts pose a substantial risk of producing human beings with unpredictable but potentially devastating health problems
column14: and WHEREAS, such human cloning attempts are grossly irresponsible and unethical

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Using undercover investigators and special computer tools, the FTC identified business opportunity advertisements that made earnings claims without including cautionary language required by the FTC's Franchise Rule.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: The investigators posed as prospective investors and listened to sales pitches from operators who hyped the business opportunity and touted the earnings potential.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Then the investigators were given "references" - supposedly successful owners and operators of the business opportunity who could verify the earnings claims.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: In the course of their investigations, the FTC staff uncovered evidence that some of the "references" didn't own or operate a business.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: They were shills - actors paid by the operations to pose as successful and prosperous owners.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Work-at-Home Schemes - While some work-at-home plans are legitimate, many are not.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Home employment schemes are among the oldest kinds of classified advertising fraud.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Work-at-Home Schemes Top Fraud - Consumers who pay for work-at-home schemes are likely to lose money, not make it, according to the National Consumers League, a nonprofit consumer advocacy organization.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: NCL's National Fraud Information Center, a telemarketing fraud hotline, released its top ten telemarketing complaints for 1999 today and work-at-home schemes were the number one fraud reported by consumers last year.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: The FTC announced the filing of one complaint targeting a work-at-home medical billing scam that allegedly made deceptive earnings claims on the Internet and in print ads to promote its $369 package of "training, software and clients."

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Overstated claims of product effectiveness.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Use of hype titles and frequent use of the word "hot" to describe an investment opportunity can indicate a scam.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: * Exaggerated claims of potential earnings, profits, or part-time earnings.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: * Claims of "inside" information.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: * Requires money for instructions or merchandise before telling you how the plan operates and tells you that no experience is necessary.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: The FTC announced the filing of one complaint targeting a work-at-home medical billing scam that allegedly made deceptive earnings claims on the Internet and in print ads to promote its $369 package of "training, software and clients."

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: The Traditional "Work-atHome" Scam Work-at-home opportunities on the Internet are no way to make money.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Flashy Internet ads typically promise a "large income" for working on projects "in great demand."

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: They require money for instructions or merchandise before telling you how the plan operates.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: They assure you of guaranteed markets and a huge demand for your handiwork.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: They tell you that no experience is necessary.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: In the most common work-at-home scheme -- envelope stuffing -- all you get for your money are instructions to place an ad like the one that was answered.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Once recruited, the only way workers make any money is to recruit other would-be workers.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: The operations ranged from envelope stuffing work-at-home schemes to snack and soda vending machine businesses.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: In some cases, like medical billing work-at-home schemes, the sellers overstate the demand for the services, according to the FTC.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: FRAUDULENT business opportunities may be promoted on Web sites and e-mailed solicitations.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: These offers make it sound easy to start a business and earn big bucks with little work.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Offers may promise top earnings through Internet-related ventures such as training to become an Internet consultant, or by doing electronic billing for doctors.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Many notorious work-at-home scams such as envelope stuffing, assembling crafts at home, coupon clipping and reading books have been revived on the Internet

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Here are some phrases signaling scams: q Make a fortune working a few hours a week.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: q No experience needed.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: q For a fee, get a list of businesses wanting home-based workers.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: q Call a 900-number for more information.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: q Make a decision now.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Envelope-stuffing solicitations promise steady income for minimal labor-for example, you'll earn $2 each time you fold a brochure and seal it in an envelope.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Craft assembly work schemes often require an investment of hundreds of dollars in equipment or supplies, and many hours of your time producing goods for a company that has promised to buy them.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: You'll pay a small fee to get started in the envelope-stuffing business.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Then, you'll learn that the email sender never had real employment to offer.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Instead, you'll get instructions on how to send the same envelope-stuffing ad in your own bulk emailings.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: If you earn any money, it will be from others who fall for the scheme you're perpetuating.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: And after spending the money and putting in the time on the craft assembly work, you are likely to find promoters who refuse to pay you, claiming that your work isn't up to their "quality standards."

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Use of hype titles and frequent use of the word "hot" to describe an investment opportunity can indicate a scam.

column9: * Claims of "inside" information.

column9: According to the FTC, the defendants e-mailed job seekers who posted their resumes on job Web sites, and advertised their work-at-home data entry positions on such Web sites and in local newspapers.

column9: What you might NOT be told is that you have to market these services to the medical community.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Another infamous work-at-home scam is envelope stuffing.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: This type of deceptive advertisement promises you information on how to make money stuffing envelopes at home.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: After you pay the promoter a "small fee," you will receive a letter telling you to place the same envelope stuffing ad in newspapers and magazines and on the Internet.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: You'll only make money if people respond to your ad.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Some promoters are so brazen as to suggest soliciting family members.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: Assembly work is also a very popular work-at-home scheme.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: In this case, you may be told that you can make thousands of dollars assembling items for a company that has promised to buy them from you.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: You must first buy certain types of equipment to produce the goods for the company.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: The equipment typically costs hundreds of dollars.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: However, after you perform the work, the business in question will usually refuse to pay you, citing lack of quality.

column5: describe work home scams promoted internet
column9: These solicitations can cost consumers anywhere from $2,000 to $8,000.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: On May 17, 1876, Lieutenant Colonel Custer led the 750 men of the 7th United States Cavalry Regiment out of Fort Abraham Lincoln, Dakota Territory.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Commanded by Brigadier General Alfred H. Terry, Custer's division was part of an expedition intended to locate and rout tribes organized for resistance under Chief Sitting Bull.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Hoping to entrap Sitting Bull in the Little Big Horn area, Terry ordered Custer to follow the Rosebud River while he brought the majority of the men down the Yellowstone River.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: After meeting at the mouth of the Little Big Horn, they planned to force the Lakota Sioux and Cheyenne back to their reservations.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: George Flanders was a soldier in a group arriving in Black Hills on June 26, 1876, a day after Custer's charge.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: On June 25, 1876, George Armstrong Custer and the 265 men under his command lost their lives in the Battle of Little Big Horn, often referred to as Custer's Last Stand.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Custer found Sitting Bull encamped on the Little Bighorn River in Montana.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Instead of waiting for Terry, the lieutenant colonel chose to wage an immediate attack.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: He divided his forces into several groups, and headed out.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Quickly encircled by their enemy, the five companies under Custer's immediate command were slaughtered in less than an hour.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Over the next two days, the remnants of the 7th Cavalry fought for their lives as they waited in vain for Custer to relieve them.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: On June 27, the Indians retreated as reinforcements arrived.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Expecting to meet Custer and prepare for battle, General Terry discovered only the bodies of Custer and his men.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Nearly a third of the men of the 7th Cavalry, including Custer and his brother, died at Little Big Horn.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: A stunning but short-lived victory for Native Americans, the Battle of Little Big Horn galvanized the public against the Indians.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: In response, federal troops poured into the Black Hills.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: Custer didn't deal with military victories and moral failures for long.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: In 1876, he and his 264 men died in an attack on Sioux and Cheyenne warriors during the Battle of the Little Big Horn in Black Hills, Montana.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: The federal government opened Black Hills to gold mining in 1875 but Native Americans refused to leave the area because of its religious significance.

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: As the U.S. military gathered to forcibly relocate the warriors, Custer's troops disregarded orders and attacked a village.

Josephy, Jr., explains how the Little Bighorn was the logical result of an Indian policy that, however fraught with independent actions, corruption, and well-intentioned philanthropy, offered only three alternatives to Native American societies: become white on your own accord

column5: give history battle big horn june 25 26 1876 referred custers stand
column9: As Jerome A. Greene argues, the Little Bighorn, a battle among skirmishes, was a pivotal moment that shaped all subsequent events.

column9: The outer layer of the earth is composed of a dozen or so large pieces called tectonic plates.

column5: global positioning system gps research monitoring earthquakes
column9: Most earthquakes result from distortion that occurs near the edges of these plates as they try to move past one another.

column5: global positioning system gps research monitoring earthquakes
column9: The Global Positioning System (GPS) satellites provide precise measurements of this movement and distortion and, thus, provide very direct information about what happens during earthquakes and very directly feed estimates of the probability of future earthquakes.
